alert.note: Alert for Jackson (Texas) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued May 15 at 6:34PM CDT until May 18 at 3:08AM CDT by NWS Houston - Galveston
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Texas... Lake Creek at Sendera Ranch Road affecting Montgomery County. San Bernard River near Boling affecting Fort Bend, Wharton and Brazoria Counties. Sandy Creek near Cordele affecting Jackson, Wharton and Colorado Counties. Lavaca River near Edna affecting Jackson County. For the West Fork San Jacinto River...including Sendera Ranch Road, Humble...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the San Bernard River...including East Bernard, Boling...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Sandy Creek...including Cordele...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Lavaca River...including Edna...Moderate flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY THURSDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Moderate flooding is occurring and moderate flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Lavaca River near Edna. * WHEN...Until early Thursday morning. * IMPACTS...At 25.0 feet, Moderate lowland flooding begins with the river one third of a mile wide near the Highway 59 bridge flooding secondary roads and bridges along the river. Livestock are isolated and potentially drown. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 3:15 AM CDT Monday the stage was 26.3 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 3:15 AM CDT Monday was 26.3 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 26.5 feet this afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage Wednesday afternoon. - Flood stage is 21.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 26.5 feet on 10/14/1997. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood && Fld Observed Forecasts (7 pm CDT) Location Stg Stg Day/Time Tue Wed Thu Lavaca River Edna 21.0 26.3 Mon 3 am CDT 23.3 19.9 17.2 &&
info.instruction: Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Be especially cautious at night when it is harder to recognize the dangers of flooding. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued Tuesday morning at 645 AM CDT.
